text:
East 8th Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of 4th Avenue, as seen from Astor Place (foreground) at Lafayette Street. The corner building mentioned (extreme right) bears No. 38 4th Avenue in the Perris, New York Insurance Map of 1854. Adjoining same is St. Ann's R. C. Church, with No's. 145, 143 and 141, progressing westward to Broadway. Across the background appears the new A. T. Stewart Building, which today (1937) is the north unit of Wanamaker's. The south unit being raised on the area occupied as shown in this view, exclusive of No. 38 4th Avenue and adjacent. In 1879, a Jacob Aberle converted the church building into a variety theatre, known as the 8th Street Theatre. About 1890, performances were given in Hebrew by native actors. It was called the Germania and German Theatre in 1897 and 1902 respectively. About 1905 it formed a portion of the present site of the aforementioned department store.

Prior to 1879.

Ewing Galloway.

Fourth Avenue, north from E. 9th Street as photographed from the traffic island at 8th Street. At the left is the north building of John Wanamaker's Department store. This occupies the 9th to 10th Street frontage. 14th Street is in the background where the perspective is lost because of the bend at Union Square. The Central Savings Bank building is at that point. Above same, and barely perceptible are the towers of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. and the Empire State buildings.

P. L. Sperr

W. P. A. photo
Five Boroughs Project

View 1: November 19, 1930
View 2: February 4, 1937

Fourth Avenue, north from E. 9th Street as photographed from the traffic island at 8th Street. At the left is the north building of John Wanamaker's Department store. This occupies the 9th to 10th Street frontage. 14th Street is in the background where the perspective is lost because of the bend at Union Square. The Central Savings Bank building is at that point. Above same, and barely perceptible are the towers of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. and the Empire State buildings.

View 2: February 4, 1937

Pedlars--Umbrellas: Itinerant umbrella repair men, at Astor Place and Fourth Avenue, Manhattan.

Victor Volmar

Early 1930's
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Umbrellas.

text:
8th Street, at the intersection of Fourth Avenue, Astor Place, and the northern end of Lafayette Street. The car track in the foreground is on 8th Street; the street car is going west on Astor Place past Bible House, which however, has its own house numbers instead of Astor Place house numbers.
Bible House was built in 1852 by the American Bible Society. In the background, on the west side of Fourth Avenue, may be seen the newer of the John Wanamaker stores, built around 1905.
August 5, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Metropolitan Tobacco Company, Fourth Avenue and Astor Place, S.W. corner.
John Wanamaker's Department Store in background.
February 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Bible House, Fourth Avenue, east side, from 8th to 9th Streets.
March 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

New Madison Avenue bus in front of American Bible House, Fourth Avenue at N. E. corner of Astor Place.
These buses in February, 1935, replaced the Madison Avenue street cars, which had been in continuous operation since 1832.
April 19, 1935.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
